Award.AwardTitle: Microfluidic Devices for Enhancing the Sensitivity of ELISA methods
Award.AbstractNarration:
Enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is a method used to detect the presence of an antibody or an antigen.This project outlines a research plan to develop microfluidic devices that can significantly increase the sensitivity of ELISA methods when compared to currently available systems. This will be achieved by selecting the concentration of ELISA reaction products in a trapping zone. Because the trapping zone in the microfluidic devices has a volume of the order of nanoliters or less,entrapment of a small number of product molecules in this region results in a relatively large concentration within it, thereby significantly enhancing the sensitivity of the assay.
In addition to characterizing and optimizing the performance of the devices described above, we will also extend their applicability to simultaneous detection of two analytes. Moreover, we will explore new protocols that could significantly simplify the fabrication and operation of the outlined microfluidic systems, thereby making them available to researchers across several disciplines and leading to a broad impact of this research on
the scientific community. The performance of the ELISA devices described above will be evaluated by side-by-side comparison with current ELISA methods in use by collaborators on this project (Dr. James Mecham from the USDA-ARS-ABADRL, Prof. Derek Smith from the Department of Kinesiology and Prof. Mark Stayton from the Department of Molecular Biology at the University of Wyoming). We anticipate determining concentrations of protein biomarkers for acute myocardial infarction and oxidative stress in serum samples, and monitoring of virus-cell receptor interactions for blue tongue virus.
Besides training graduate and undergraduate students, educational activities aimed at disseminating the results of our research to a broad range of audiences, as well as directly involving high school students in research activities will be pursued as part of this project. This will include incorporating ELISA methods into a graduate level chemistry course at the University of Wyoming, and initiating a summer research apprentice program for high school students. At the same time, the PI will also develop an outreach program with the Central Wyoming College that has about 20% Native American and 80% first-generation college student population to broaden the participation of minorities and underprivileged communities.
The research findings from this work will be published in scientific journals and presented at national/international conferences. In addition, the PI will also post some of the project outcomes, including protocols for carrying out the new assay methods at his research group website http://www.uwyo.edu/ddutta

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of this work was to develop highly sensitive ELISA methods exploiting the greater controllability of fluid and analyte transport within microfluidic networks. The core of our strategy for improving ELISA sensitivity involved a charge based selective (electrophoretic) and/or advective (electroosmotic or hydrodynamic) transport of the target analyte and/or the enzyme reaction product to a trapping zone of some type, where these molecules are concentrated and later directly/indirectly detected. In a conventional ELISA, the analyte and/or the enzyme reaction product is usually present in a relatively large volume and can be only reliably detected when its concentration is sufficiently high. If the same number of analyte/reporter molecules are localized in one hundredth (or less of) the volume, the sensitivity of the assay is correspondingly increased. Thus, the methods proposed here can take full advantage of all ELISA technology developed to date; we are "simply" improving the detectability of the target analyte/enzyme reaction product. Interestingly, a corollary benefit of our strategy includes broadening of the range of substrates suitable for use in enzyme reactions.

The research objectives described above were realized over the course of this grant through completion of the following 3 sub-projects. The first one of these examined the possibility of improving ELISA sensitivity by accumulating the target analyte molecules from the bulk sample in a detection region via electrokinetic means. These accumulated molecules were simultaneously immunocaptured on the microchannel surface in the detection zone which was previously coated with capture antibodies specific to the analyte. Upon incubating this assay surface with an enzyme-conjugated antibody followed by introducing a suitable enzyme substrate solution around it, the fluorescence signal produced in the detection region was observed to be over 200-fold greater than that realized in the corresponding experiment without analyte accumulation. Not surprisingly, the reported approach also increased the non-specific binding of proteins in the detection zone leading to a greater signal from the blank assay, but only by a factor of 2.These results led to an overall reduction in the limit of detection (LOD) for the target analyte by more than 100-fold compared to that realized on commercial ELISA plates (see Figure 1).

In the second sub-project, an alternative approach to improving ELISA sensitivity was explored in which the signaling species was concentrated in the solution phase to improve its detectability, and hence that of the target analyte, based on the field amplified stacking (FAS) technique. To this end, the enzyme reaction product molecules produced in the ELISA method were transported towards a high ionic-strength buffer stream in a microfluidic channel while applying a voltage drop across the merging region. A sharp change in the electric field around the junction of the two liquid streams abruptly slowed down the negatively charged signaling species leading to the reported concentration effect. The resulting enhancement in the detectability of the enzyme reaction product significantly improved the signal-to-noise ratio in the system thereby reducing the smallest detectable analyte concentration. Applying the above-described approach, we were able to detect mouse anti-BSA and human TNF-alpha at concentrations nearly 60-fold lower than that possible on commercial microwell plates (see Figure 2).
